III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth moved into ILP 2.5 weeks ago and reported their living
conditions are unfit, including a possible mouse or rat infestation.
The youth also reported concerns with her mattress.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant – On 2/29/2024 Complainant was interviewed by
phone. She reported recently meeting with Youth A and Youth A’s
mother for an intake appointment during which time Youth A
expressed concerns with the home in which she is living. Youth A
reported there are mice in the home and when she throws her
clothes on the floor, she is afraid to pick them up in case there is a
mouse under them. Youth A said there are traps in the home that
catch a lot of mice. Youth A also reported concerns with her
mattress. Complainant stated Youth A wasn’t very clear on what
those concerns were but made a statement that her mattress had
springs sticking out. Complainant was unsure if this meant springs
were sticking through the mattress covering or if Youth A could
feel the springs inside the mattress. Complainant added Youth A
might have been high at the time of her intake meeting, so Youth
A did not provide clear or detailed information.
Program Director – On 2/29/2024 Program director was
interviewed by phone. He reported Youth A was initially placed in
an Independent Living Plus (ILP) home in the flint area, but she
was moved to an ILP home in Lansing a few weeks ago. He
reported that youth are not supposed to have food in their rooms,
but a previous youth in that home was eating and keeping food in
her room after which they started noticing mouse activity in the
home. He stated they never had a mouse problem before that
youth arrived. The staff of the home are continually reminding the
youth currently in the home they are not to have food in their
rooms. He stated the agency has a monthly contract with Orkin
exterminators who recently came out and completed an analysis
of the home after which they provided an $8000 estimate to patch
2

up potential entry points for mice. Program Director stated the
estimate was provided to the landlord of the home and the
landlord indicated he would do the patchwork. Program Director
stated when Youth A moved into the home, she was provided a
mattress and bed, but Youth A did not set up her bed, rather kept
a mattress on the floor. He stated he called the staff at the home
yesterday and told them to set up Youth A’s bed for her since she
hadn’t yet done so.
Staff 1 – On 3/4/2024 Staff 1 was interviewed in person at the
Independent Living Home. Upon arriving at the home, Staff 1
stated Youth A knew she would be interviewed today but was not
home. Staff 1 reported Youth A left the home the previous day and
said she would be back on the day of our scheduled meeting but
had not yet returned. Staff 1 reported the home is being treated for
mice by exterminators. She stated she has neither seen nor heard
any mouse activity, but other staff have. She reported the
exterminators are going to be coming out to treat the attic because
that is where they are finding the most mouse activity. Staff 1
stated the attic entrance is located at the top of the closet in Youth
A’s room. Staff 1 stated she recently set up a bed for Youth A.
She stated Youth A was sleeping on a mattress on the floor or the
couch, despite there being a box spring and bed frame available
to her.
Foster Care Worker – On 3/5/2024 Youth A’s foster care worker
was interviewed by phone. He reported he visited Youth A at the
home yesterday. He reported her room was filthy and there was
food present in the room. He stated the rest of the house was
clean. He stated he is aware that there have been mice in the
house and a company is treating the home. He stated he has no
concerns with the home and Youth A is worsening the situation by
bringing food into her room when she knows she is not supposed
to. Foster Care Worker stated Youth A had a frame and mattress
for her bed, but she kept taking the mattress off the frame and
sleeping on just the mattress. He stated she previously did not
have a box spring on the bed, but she now has one.
Youth A – Attempts were made to interview Youth A in person on
3/4/2024, by text message on 3/5/2024, and by phone on
3/15/2024. On 3/15/2024, Foster Care Worker was contacted
regarding inability to reach Youth A to which Foster Care Worker
responded Youth A is AWOL and no longer has a phone number.
TOUR OBSERVATION
3

On 3/4/2024 a walkthrough of the home was completed. The main
living areas of the home, including the kitchen, dining area, living
room, and bathroom were clean and tidy. No evidence of mouse
activity was observed. Youth A’s room was viewed and appeared
very cluttered and unkept. The floor was covered in dirty clothing
and her desk was strewn with wrappers and fast-food
bags/containers. The entrance to the attic was observed in the
ceiling of the closet. It was noted the room smelled strongly of
marijuana. Staff 1 stated Youth A’s worker came to visit her a few
days ago and found marijuana laying out on the desk. Staff 1
stated she has had to report Youth A for possessing and using
vapes and marijuana multiple times. The bedroom of the other
youth living in the home was viewed. That room was clean and
tidy. It was noted the room smelled like food and there was a
takeout container of food sitting on that youth’s desk. The
remaining two bedrooms, both of which were unoccupied, were
viewed. One bedroom was nearly empty other than a few small
items, the other room contained spare bedframes, mattresses,
box springs, and bags full of a former youth’s belongings.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
• Orkin Special Service Agreement for treatment of rodents
on 1/9/2024
• Orkin Commercial Service Agreement to provide monthly
treatment for 1-year dated 1/9/2024.
• Orkin-Therm Service Agreement Estimate dated 1/9/2024.
• Youth A’s case record documenting she is AWOL as of
3/6/2024.
Analysis The home appears clean and safe, and the agency is actively
addressing the concerns of mice in the home. Additionally, Youth
A was provided an appropriate bed; therefore, no violation is
established
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
